questions.questionText: A nuclear power plant operates continuously at a thermal power of 3000 MW and converts 35% of this thermal power into electricity. It produces 20 cubic meters of high-level radioactive waste per year. Calculate the current volume of high-level radioactive waste produced per megawatt-hour (MWh) of electricity generated.

steps.stepText: Let's start by calculating the electrical power output from the thermal power using the given conversion efficiency. Identify the correct relation to compute the electrical power from the thermal power and efficiency.
steps.stepText2: Calculate the electrical power output from the thermal power using the given conversion efficiency.

steps.stepText: Great, now using the calculated electrical power output, compute the total annual electrical energy generated. Please choose the correct formula that relates power, time, and energy.
steps.stepText2: Compute the total annual electrical energy generated in $!$MWh$!$.

steps.stepText: Finally, determine how much waste is produced per MWh of electricity by dividing the total annual radioactive waste volume by the annual energy production.

questions.questionText: In a nuclear weapons design lab, engineers are working with Plutonium-239 ($!$^{239}Pu$!$). After modifications, the fission Q-value is measured as $!$2.0 \times 10^{14}$!$ J/kg and the mass difference per fission event is $!$2.22 \times 10^{-12}$!$ kg. If the initial design uses $!$6.0$!$ kg of Plutonium-239 and all of it undergoes fission, calculate the total energy released from the modified design.

steps.stepText: Let's begin by identifying the physical meaning of the fission Q-value. Please select the description that best explains what the fission Q-value represents in this context.

options.optionText: $!$\text{It is the energy released per unit mass during the fission process.}$!$
$!$\text{It is the total energy released by the entire mass of the fuel.}$!$
$!$\text{It is the mass defect per fission event.}$!$

steps.stepText: Great! Now, determine the correct mathematical relationship to calculate the total energy released when a certain mass undergoes fission. Which formula correctly relates the fission Q-value and the mass of the fuel?

Now that you have identified the correct relationship, use it to calculate the total energy released. Multiply the fission Q-value, $!$2.0 \times 10^{14}$!$ J/kg, by the total mass, $!$6.0$!$ kg, to find the total energy.
